history.content:
Actually the second half of CS 70 is all about basic stats stuff. If you do well then it's enough to prepare you for the probability part of data 100. If not, then probably it's not a great idea for you to pursue data science since there is going to be a lot of probably stuff involved. However, don't simply conclude you are not good at stat because you didn't do well in CS 70. I also didn't do well in the second half of CS 70 but after that (a year from now), I still found I actually enjoy probability theory pretty much (and did well in the probably part of other classes). I guess the reason is that CS 70 is a tough class. So if you have time, try self-study data 8 to see if you are interested in exploring data science. 

Data 100 + CS 170 + CS 160 would be ok (medium to heavy work load) if you manage your time well. However, Data 8 + 170 + 160 will leave you a fair amount of time to participate in recruiting.

__________________________________________________________________________________________________

For Fall '18, Data 8 is a hard prereq for Data 100 (you cannot enroll without it, even on calcentral), so you basically have only one choice.

children.subject: if you look under the reserve seats for stat c100 for fall 18. I don't think so other than taking data8 itself.

Check out the Data 100 FAQs: http://www.ds100.org/fa18faq

They say there will be a petition form for students who haven't taken Data 8 (or don't meet the other registration criteria) to ask for an exception to enroll.
im confused on data 8 being a hard prereq for data 100. where was this announced and is there a way to get past that?

history.content:
Which one should I take if I have 0 stats background? I'm not actually sure if I want to pursue data science tbh because I know nothing about it, so I wanted to explore it a bit.

I've already taken CS 61A, am currently in 70 (not doing well), and am retaking 61B this summer.

I'm a rising junior and I plan on taking CS 170 and 160 next fall with either Data class. Would this be a good workload?

Or should I consider taking an upperdiv cogsci class (which would be reading-heavy) since I'm a CogSci major + intended cs (depending on my grades)?

I'm looking for a lighter workload because I heard fall recruiting can get intense, and I think I'll struggle based on my performance in 70.
history.subject: Data C8 or Data C100 + course load advice
